text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.35.19, Financial Accounting, User Fees.
IRM 1.35.19.1.3(g), Responsibilities – Added the Government Payables and Funds Management office, previously identiﬁed in the narrative but not included in this section.

IRM 1.35.19.3(4), 31 USC 9701, Fees and Charges for Government Services and Things of Value - Updated to add the following fees: (c) Estate tax closing letters and (g) Preparer tax identiﬁcation numbers.

IRM 1.35.19.16, Types of IRS User Fees – Updated to add the following fees: (3) Estate tax closing letters and (7) Preparer tax identiﬁcation numbers. Also updated cross-references throughout document to match the resulting updated section numbers.
IRM 1.35.19.16.3, Estate Tax Closing Letters – Added new paragraph describing a new user fee for taxpayers requesting estate tax closing letters.
Throughout IRM - Updated office names, acronyms and formatting to comply with new writing guidance and made minor writing edits for clarity and precision.
IRM 1.35.19, User Fees, dated July 26, 2019, is superseded.
AUDIENCE
Business unit ﬁnance offices and employees responsible for managing user fee activities.

and (
) Purpose: The User Fees IRM provides information for implementing user fees and reviewing user fee activities, rates and reports. (
) Audience: Business unit ﬁnance offices and employees responsible for managing user fee activities consult this guidance. (
) Policy Owner: The CFO is responsible for this IRM. (
) Program Owner: The CFO’s Cost Accounting and User Fees office oversees user fee activities. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Business units that charge user fees implement this program. (
) Program Goals: This helps ensure internal controls for user fee collection are implemented and activity cost calculations are accurate and consistent. (
) The IRS implemented user fees when the Independent Offices Appropriations Act of
was passed. This act, codiﬁed by
USC

, Fees and charges for Government services and things of value, authorizes agencies to prescribe regulations that establish charges where the government provides special beneﬁts to a recipient beyond those given to the general public. Regu- lations implementing user fees are subject to policies prescribed by the presi- dent in the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Circular A-
, User Charges. When the IRS began implementing user fees under this authority, receipts were deposited to the government’s general fund. (
) Subsequent legislation permitted the IRS to retain and spend a portion of the user fees collected. The Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations Act of
authorized the IRS to expend up to $

million ﬁscal year of new or increased user fee receipts based on the cost of providing services. The annual spending cap was eliminated in the Transportation, Treasury, Housing and Urban Development, the Judiciary, the District of Columbia, and the Independent Agencies Appropriations Act of
) The Bipartisan Budget Act of

modiﬁed user fee requirements for install- ment agreements, limiting fees to those in effect at its enactment and waiving fees for low-income taxpayers who enter into direct debit installment agree- ments. It also established reimbursement for low-income taxpayers who completed an installment agreement and were unable to make electronic debit payments. (

) This section provides responsibilities for the: a. CFO and Deputy CFO b. Associate CFO for Financial Management and Deputy Associate CFO Administrative Financial Management c. Cost Accounting and User Fees office d. Custodial Accounting office e. Financial Reporting office f. Financial Management Systems office g. Government Payables and Funds Management office h. Associate CFO for Corporate Budget i. Information Technology division j. Business units Deputy CFO (
) The CFO and Deputy CFO oversee the IRS user fee program’s policies and controls that ensure compliance with applicable authorities. CFO for Management Associate Administrative Management (

) The Associate CFO for Financial Management and Deputy Associate CFO Administrative Financial Management are responsible for ensuring policies, procedures, standards and controls for costing user fee activities and for reporting collections and projections are in place; and for overseeing: a. The biennial review process, including obtaining approval for user fee rates and coordinating OMB Circular A-

, User Charges, full cost re- quirements. b. The annual ﬁnancial statement audit, which attests to the reasonableness of user fee collections, and other audits performed by the Government Accountability Office or the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Adminis- tration relating to user fees. c. Implementation of new user fees. Accounting and Office (

) The Cost Accounting and User Fees office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Management and is responsible for: a. Developing policies, leading biennial reviews and providing guidance the business units for implementing and monitoring user fees. b. Providing the annual corporate overhead rate to the business units. c. Monitoring volumes and revenue in comparison to projections and re- searching unexpected variances. d. Validating and monitoring user fee costing and processes. e. Developing Uniﬁed Work Requests (UWR) for user fees.
Financial Accounting Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H (
This section provides responsibilities for the:
The CFO and Deputy CFO oversee the IRS user fee program’s policies and controls that ensure compliance with applicable authorities.
a. The biennial review process, including obtaining approval for user fee rates and coordinating OMB Circular A-

, User Charges, full cost re- quirements. b. The annual ﬁnancial statement audit, which attests to the reasonableness of user fee collections, and other audits performed by the Government Accountability Office or the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Adminis- tration relating to user fees. c. Implementation of new user fees.

Developing policies, leading biennial reviews and providing guidance to the business units for implementing and monitoring user fees. Providing the annual corporate overhead rate to the business units. Monitoring volumes and revenue in comparison to projections and re
searching unexpected variances. Validating and monitoring user fee costing and processes. Developing Uniﬁed Work Requests (UWR) for user fees.

Comparing actual user fee deposits and Central Accounting Reporting System (CARS) monthly reports to supporting documentation received from the business units, including explanations for variances. Preparing user fee collection reports, the President’s Budget Receipt Estimates and Government Accountability Office user fee deliverables the ﬁnancial statement audit. Working with the business units to review and revise the collection processes for new and existing user fees, including Pay.gov and the Over the Counter Channel Application (OTCnet). Approving the year
end user fee entry prepared by the Financial Reporting office prior to close.
) Custodial Accounting (

) The Custodial Accounting office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for Custodial Financial Management and is responsible for providing: a. Monthly Redesigned Revenue Accounting and Control System (RRACS) analysis reports to the Financial Reporting office by the fourth day of month. b. Support for system changes and UWRs for campus systems. c. Monthly interim RRACS reports to the Financial Reporting office and Cost Accounting and User Fees office three business days before the end of each month. d. Year-end RRACS reports to the Financial Reporting office and the Cost Accounting and User Fees office within two business days after the year-end. e. Monthly reports, by campus, of installment agreement user fee collec- tions to the Cost Accounting and User Fees office.
) Financial Reporting (
) The Financial Reporting office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for istrative Financial Management and is responsible for: a. Preparing and posting a non-standard Treasury Form

entry into Integrated Financial System (IFS) monthly and at ﬁscal year-end to record user fee collections initially recorded in RRACS. b. Preparing monthly analyses comparing Central Accounting Reporting System (CARS) data and IFS user fee activity, and reconciling budgetary and proprietary user fee general ledger balances.
) Financial Management Systems Office (

) The Financial Management Systems office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Management and is responsible for maintain- ing the exchange of information between IFS, the Transcript Delivery System and Pay.gov.
) Government Payables Funds Management (

) The Government Payables and Funds Management office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Management and is sible for: a. Depositing and recording checks received for user fees b. Notifying business units of any user fee receipts originating outside the business units.
The Custodial Accounting office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for Custodial Financial Management and is responsible for providing:

a. Monthly Redesigned Revenue Accounting and Control System (RRACS) analysis reports to the Financial Reporting office by the fourth day of month. b. Support for system changes and UWRs for campus systems. c. Monthly interim RRACS reports to the Financial Reporting office and Cost Accounting and User Fees office three business days before the end of each month. d. Year
end RRACS reports to the Financial Reporting office and the Cost Accounting and User Fees office within two business days after the year
end. e. Monthly reports, by campus, of installment agreement user fee collec
tions to the Cost Accounting and User Fees office.
(1) The Financial Reporting office reports to the Deputy Associate CFO for Admin- istrative Financial Management and is responsible for:

Posting weekly installment agreement provided through an annual UWR to Control D. Producing monthly installment agreement and offer in compromise reports provided through an annual UWR to the CFO Accounts Receiv
able Management System. Providing nine
and twelve
month ﬁles of installment agreement user fees to CFO based on UWR requirements.
reports provided through an annual UWR to the CFO Accounts Receiv- able Management System. c. Providing nine- and twelve-month ﬁles of installment agreement user to CFO based on UWR requirements. (

) The business units are responsible for: a. Collecting and reporting user fees within their program areas. b. Developing quarterly estimates of projected volumes and revenue, annual estimates for ten subsequent years for the Cost Accounting User Fees office. c. Providing the Cost Accounting and User Fees office with monthly reports and explanations of actual to budget variances within three of the end of the month. d. Executing the biennial review of user fee activities, including maintaining documentation to support cost estimates. e. Maintaining and tracking information on revenue and volumes to support ﬁnancial audits. f. Implementing changes to legacy systems used to monitor user fees. g. Sending the daily deposit tickets that support IFS revenue entries to Cost Accounting and User Fees office within

hours. h. Researching debit vouchers and updating case load systems’ payment information. i. Submitting refund schedules with original collection dates to the Cost counting and User Fees office. j. Reviewing activities annually for potential new user fees or necessary revisions to existing user fee rates or activities. (

) The following reports are used to review the user fee program. a. Commissioner’s chart b. Biennial Review of User Fee Charges report c. Offer in compromise analysis d. Installment agreement analysis (
) Program effectiveness is determined by the Cost Accounting and User Fees office comparing actual user fee collections to the business unit projections and analyzing variances.
Controls (

) The Cost Accounting and User Fees office is responsible for: a. Analyzing monthly volume and revenue information. b. Reviewing supporting documentation to ensure user fee collections are classiﬁed and recorded correctly. c. Developing the corporate overhead rate and managing the allocation cycles to ensure consistent costing methodologies for business units d. Reviewing the business unit costing documents submitted during the biennial review to ensure accuracy and consistency. e. Ensuring preparers, reviewers and approvers have separate roles and responsibilities. f. Saving reports and supporting documentation on a shared drive with access limited to users with the appropriate job requirements. (

) Business units are responsible for: a. Reviewing user fee charges every two years to ensure rates are adjusted to reﬂect changes in costs and to determine if other agency programs should assess fees. b. Implementing internal controls (e.g., management reviews, system access, etc.) applicable to their speciﬁc user fee processes. (

) The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program. a. Art - Paintings, sculptures, watercolors, prints, drawings, ceramics, antique furniture, decorative arts, textiles, carpets, silver, rare manu- scripts and other similar objects. b. Costs - The monetary value of resources used in performing activities in acquiring or producing goods and services. c. Corporate overhead rate - The rate calculated annually by the Cost counting and User Fees office and applied to total labor and beneﬁt to determine the full cost of providing services. d. Direct costs - The costs incurred directly by programs due to their budget execution. These include salaries, beneﬁts, consulting, materials, supplies, etc. e. Full cost - All costs used in generating activities, products and services, including direct, indirect and imputed costs. f. Imputed costs - The unreimbursed costs required to be recognized by accounting standards. g. Indirect costs - The costs of resources that are jointly or commonly used and cannot be reasonably identiﬁed and charged to a speciﬁc activity. h. Market price - Price for goods, resources or services based on a com- petitive open market that creates neither a shortage nor a surplus of goods, resources or services. i. Overhead - Support costs not directly identiﬁable to a business unit func- tional area. j. Special beneﬁts - Privileges, goods or services that give recipients beneﬁts beyond those available to the general public. k. Support costs - The business unit costs that primarily support other IRS business units. l. Sustaining costs - The business unit costs that support IRS Servicewide operations. m. User fees - Charges levied by a federal agency on individuals or entities directly beneﬁting from a service provided by a government program or Fees

a. Analyzing monthly volume and revenue information. b. Reviewing supporting documentation to ensure user fee collections classiﬁed and recorded correctly. c. Developing the corporate overhead rate and managing the allocation cycles to ensure consistent costing methodologies for business units d. Ensuring preparers, reviewers and approvers have separate roles and responsibilities. f. Saving reports and supporting documentation on a shared drive with access limited to users with the appropriate job requirements.

User fees - Charges levied by a federal agency on individuals or entities directly beneﬁting from a service provided by a government program or
activity. User fees are charged for federal activities that provide recipients with beneﬁts greater than those provided to the general public.

, Fees and charges for Government services and things of provides for the collection of user fees where the government provides beneﬁts to recipients beyond those given to the general public. The IRS collects fees not covered by other legislation under this authority. (

The IRS implements user fees under Section 9701 by regulation.
) Section
requires the IRS to charge full cost or obtain a waiver from to charge less than full cost. (
) The IRS collects fees under Section
for the following activities: a. Installment agreements, IRM
b. Offers in compromise, IRM
c. Estate tax closing letters, IRM
d. Enrollments and enrollment renewals of enrolled actuaries, IRM
e. Enrollments and enrollment renewals of enrolled agents, IRM
f. Special enrollment examinations for enrolled agents, IRM
g. Preparer tax identiﬁcation numbers, IRM
A-
, User (
) The OMB Circular A-

, User Charges, provides guidance to government agencies for establishing and charging user fees for special beneﬁts provided to recipients beyond those given to the general public. The charge imposed recovers full cost to the federal government for providing the special beneﬁt the market price. (
) Full cost includes all direct and indirect costs to any part of the federal govern- ment for providing a good, resource or service. (

) A special beneﬁt enables the beneﬁciary to obtain more immediate or substan- tial gains or values than those given to the general public, provides business stability or contributes to public conﬁdence in the business activity or beneﬁ- ciary, or is performed at the request of or for the convenience of the recipient. It is beyond the services regularly received by other members of the same industry or group or the general public. (

) Market price is the price for the good, resource or service based on competi- tion in open markets and creates neither a shortage nor a surplus of the When a substantial competitive demand exists, competitive bidding or reference to prevailing prices in competitive markets for goods, resources or services that are similar to those provided by the government determines market price. (

) Agency heads or their designees may recommend to OMB exceptions to the general policy when the cost of collecting the fees would represent an unduly part of the fee for the activity or any other condition exists that, in the opinion of the agency head or his or her designee, justiﬁes an exception. IRS considers the implication of the user fee on low-income taxpayers, tax adminis- tration, taxpayer rights and cost of collecting the fees when determining the user fee rate and whether to request a waiver. USC Section
, Internal Revenue Service user fees, requires the IRS collect a user fee for ruling letters, opinion letters, determination letters and other similar requests. (
) The IRS fees, including user fees under Section
, are implemented through the issuance of published guidance. (
) This legislation authorizes the IRS to charge a reasonable fee; however, it a ﬂoor based on the historical average cost.

) The IRS user fees collected under this authority are used for historical conser- vation easement donation enforcement activities.
) Freedom of Act (
) The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), allows the IRS to charge a user fee for providing certain information covered under the Act to the general public. IRM
) The IRS implements FOIA user fees through an announcement or revenue procedure. (
) This Act requires agencies to limit fees to reasonable standard charges for document search, duplication and review. (

per year for a program to certify professional employer organizations. IRM
) and Deposit of Fees (
) The IRS receives user fee remittances at campuses and through lockbox rangements, Post Office (PO) Boxes, a mail room at the CFO offices in Beckley, WV, and Pay.gov. (
) A lockbox is a PO Box established by a ﬁnancial institution to receive payments made to the IRS. The ﬁnancial institution receives, deposits and reports payments on Standard Form
, Deposit Ticket. (

) The IRS uses the following Bureau of the Fiscal Service applications to paper checks to electronic funds transfer: a. Over the Counter Channel Application (OTCnet) b. Remittance Strategy Paper Check Conversion (RS-PCC) (
) The Government Payables and Funds Management office deposits paper checks using the Over the Counter Channel Application (OTCnet). (

) Pay.gov is a secure governmentwide collection portal administered by the Bureau of the Fiscal Service. Customers using Pay.gov may pay by Automated Clearing House debit or credit card. a. The Bureau of the Fiscal Service absorbs all credit card fees for user collections. b. Credit card transactions on one card cannot exceed $
on same day. (
) The IRS records user fee deposits on one of two general ledgers: IFS or RRACS. The Financial Reporting office enters user fees originating in RRACS into IFS through a non-standard Treasury
entry. Fees
page No.
H (
) Internal Revenue Manual
The Government Payables and Funds Management office deposits paper checks using the Over the Counter Channel Application (OTCnet).
Fees (

) Business units are required to consider full costs and apply the IRS corporate overhead rate when developing user fee costing. Full cost for providing the good or service includes direct, indirect and imputed costs. The cost of activi- ties includes: a. Labor and beneﬁts b. Service and consulting c. Rent and building costs d. Depreciation e. Travel, training and communication f. Supplies (including equipment, printing and postage) g. Enforcement (
) Business units identify labor and beneﬁt costs for the user fee activity. Labor costs include both direct and indirect time. (

) The Cost Accounting and User Fees office provides the business units with corporate overhead rate to account for non-labor costs and all other support and sustaining costs paid by the IRS. Expenses not paid by the IRS are not included in the IRS corporate overhead rate. of User (
) The IRS performs a review every two years to recalculate existing user fee activity costs and consider other activities for which a user fee should be imposed. (
) Business unit strategy and ﬁnance offices provide the cost of user fee and provide calculations and recommendations for maintaining, increasing decreasing user fees within
days of the request. The cost analysis considers the effect on voluntary compliance and the corresponding increase to enforcement cost. (
) The Associate CFO for Financial Management prepares the biennial review report and presents the results and business unit recommendations to the CFO. (
) The CFO submits the biennial review to the IRS commissioner by September
th of the review year. (

) The Associate CFO for Financial Management works with OMB, Treasury, business units and other stakeholders to implement fee adjustments if a change in rate or a new fee is implemented, or if a waiver for a less-than-full- cost user fee is recommended. (

) Business units are required to monitor services and activities to determine potential effect of the user fee on services and activities during the annual budget cycle. The business units should consider whether evidence exists newly implemented user fees or changes to existing fees have affected tax administration and make appropriate recommendations. (

) Business units are required to review services and activities for potential user fees during the annual budget cycle. When performing this review, the business units consider the: a. Voluntary nature of the user fee activities; the IRS does not charge taxpayers for special services that they do not request. b. Identiﬁable beneﬁt to a speciﬁc taxpayer.
Financial Accounting Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H (
The Associate CFO for Financial Management prepares the biennial review report and presents the results and business unit recommendations to the
The IRS avoids fees that increase enforcement costs, reduce voluntary compli- ance or otherwise create difficulties in achieving the IRS’s mission.
When potential user fees are identiﬁed, the business units submit the following information to the Cost Accounting and User Fees office:

) The IRS charges a fee to recover the cost of activities for creating and managing Installment Agreement (IA) payment plans. These activities include answering phone calls, printing and mailing notices, and processing IA collec- tions. The IRS must set the fees at full cost, not to exceed the amounts in effect at the enactment of the Bipartisan Budget Act of
(February
), or obtain a waiver from OMB. IRM

) An IA is an agreement between the IRS and the taxpayer that allows the taxpayer to pay his or her outstanding tax liability with monthly installment payments. The taxpayer agrees to pay a user fee for the cost of establishing new, revised or reinstated IA. The IRS charges an origination fee to establish new agreement, revise an existing agreement, or reinstate an agreement after the taxpayer defaults on an agreement or an agreement has been terminated. The SB/SE division administers the IA program. (

) A direct debit installment agreement automatically debits the taxpayer’s bank account for a monthly transfer to the IRS on a date pre-selected by the taxpayer. These agreements have a lower user fee compared to non-direct debit agreements and the fee is waived for low-income taxpayers. (

) An online payment agreement is established by the taxpayer at IRS.gov. The fee is lower than the fee charged when a taxpayer applies using other methods (phone, mail or in-person) because online payment agreements do not require employee assistance. (

) A voice balance due agreement is established by the taxpayer through the automated phone service. The fee is lower than the fee charged when a taxpayer applies using other methods (agreements established with live phone assistance, by mail or in-person) because voice balance due agreements do not require employee assistance. (
) Taxpayers with incomes at or below

% of the Department of Health and Human Services poverty guidelines, which are adjusted and published annually, qualify for a reduced low-income user fee. User fees are waived for low-income taxpayers entering into IAs on or after April

, if they agree to make electronic payments through a direct debit IA. Low-income taxpayers who indicate they are unable to make electronic payments through a debit in- strument will receive a reimbursement of the reduced user fee upon completion of the IA. A low-income taxpayer will not be reimbursed for the user fee if the IA is terminated. Low-income taxpayers are identiﬁed systemically using their most recently ﬁled tax return. Taxpayers who are not identiﬁed as low-income, but believe they meet the requirements for low-income status, must complete Form
, Application for Reduced User Fee for Installment Agreements, within
days of receipt of the IA acceptance letter. (

) The IRS receives IA fees with installment tax payments through a lockbox or the Electronic Federal Tax Payment System. Campuses record the payments in RRACS as tax revenue. The IA fees and the tax payments are not sepa- rately identiﬁable, so a separate process reclassiﬁes user fee collections from tax revenue to record the IA user fee revenue. (

) The IRS IT division staff executes a weekly automated utility program, the IA User Fee Sweep Program, to reclassify the Integrated Data Retrieval System IA user fee collections from tax revenue to user fee revenue. The program reviews all tax modules in the taxpayer’s account in IA status and veriﬁes a user fee has been received. If not, the program looks for subsequent tax

(
) Taxpayers with incomes at or below

% of the Department of Health and Human Services poverty guidelines, which are adjusted and published annually, qualify for a reduced low-income user fee. User fees are waived for low-income taxpayers entering into IAs on or after April

, if they agree to make electronic payments through a direct debit IA. Low-income taxpayers who indicate they are unable to make electronic payments through a debit in- strument will receive a reimbursement of the reduced user fee upon completion of the IA. A low-income taxpayer will not be reimbursed for the fee if the IA is terminated. Low-income taxpayers are identiﬁed systemically using their most recently ﬁled tax return. Taxpayers who are not identiﬁed as low-income, but believe they meet the requirements for low-income status, must complete Form
, Application for Reduced User Fee for Installment Agreements, within
days of receipt of the IA acceptance letter. (

) The IRS receives IA fees with installment tax payments through a lockbox or the Electronic Federal Tax Payment System. Campuses record the payments in RRACS as tax revenue. The IA fees and the tax payments are not sepa- rately identiﬁable, so a separate process reclassiﬁes user fee collections from tax revenue to record the IA user fee revenue. (

) The IRS IT division staff executes a weekly automated utility program, the IA User Fee Sweep Program, to reclassify the Integrated Data Retrieval System IA user fee collections from tax revenue to user fee revenue. The program reviews all tax modules in the taxpayer’s account in IA status and veriﬁes a user fee has been received. If not, the program looks for subsequent tax

payments sufficient to pay the user fee. If sufficient payments have been received, the program transfers the user fee amount from the tax module the user fee module, reversing the tax payment and recording the user fee payment. (

) The IT division staff provides the Cost Accounting and User Fees office a weekly report that details the volume of user fees collected from the weekly sweep program and a monthly master ﬁle report with detailed revenue data. Accountants in the Cost Accounting and User Fees office reconcile the data with the RRACS revenue, compare the volume with the previous year and expected year-to-date volumes, and research unexpected variances. (

) Each October, the Cost Accounting and User Fees office estimates the tax revenue received in the prior ﬁscal year that will be reclassiﬁed as user fee revenue in the current ﬁscal year during the sweep process and records an accrual entry, if necessary. Compromise (
) The IRS charges a fee to recover the cost for reviewing and processing an Offer in Compromise (OIC) settlement. The IRS must set the fees at full or obtain a waiver from OMB. IRM

) An OIC is an agreement between a taxpayer and the IRS that settles a tax liability for less than the full amount owed. The IRS accepts an OIC when there is doubt as to liability or collectability, or where acceptance would promote effective tax administration. The SB/SE division administers the program. (
) Taxpayers submit Form
, Offer in Compromise, and pay the appropriate application fee (user fee) stated on the form. Taxpayers meeting the IRS income guidelines are exempt from the application fee. (

) The IRS retains the user fee for a processable OIC, except where the offer accepted under Effective Tax Administration or Doubt as to Collectability Special Circumstances – Hardship criteria. The IRS returns the taxpayer’s check for the user fee and any deposits if the OIC is not processable. (

) The Brookhaven and Memphis campuses receive OIC user fees, which are initially recorded in master ﬁle and RRACS as payments against the taxpayer’s debt. During weekly processing, the IT division runs a program that summa- rizes the payments and generates a journal entry at the general ledger level, reducing the RRACS general ledger account balance for tax receipts and creasing the OIC user fee account for the fees. (

) The IT division provides a monthly master ﬁle detail report of user fee tions to the Cost Accounting and User Fees office to analyze and identify payments that do not equal the user fee amount. Non-matching payments sent to SB/SE for correction. (

) has been accepted by the IRS with any necessary adjustments. The letter documents that the

) The IRS charges a fee to recover the cost for processing new enrolled applications and renewals. The IRS must set the fees at full cost or obtain waiver from OMB. IRM

) Enrolled agents are individuals who successfully completed the Special ment Examination process or who qualiﬁed based on prior IRS employment and have been approved to practice before the IRS. The Return Preparer Office administers the enrolled agent program and grants permission to practice before the IRS. (
) Individuals seeking enrollment are subject to a tax compliance check. (

) Individuals who pass the Special Enrollment Examination are provided an rollment card, which must be renewed with the IRS every three years. agents must register for a preparer tax identiﬁcation number, which must renewed annually. (

The IRS charges a fee to recover the cost for overseeing the administration of the Special Enrollment Examination, including developing and approving ex- amination questions, recording test results and managing the program. The IRS must set the fee at full cost or obtain a waiver from OMB. IRM
) The Special Enrollment Examination is administered by a vendor that schedules the examination and collects the user fee. (
) Individuals pay a user fee each time they sit for a part of the Special ment Examination. (
) The vendor that administers the examination submits the Special Enrollment Examination user fees to the IRS through Pay.gov. Numbers (

) The IRS charges a fee to recover the cost of administering the preparer identiﬁcation number (PTIN) application and renewal program. The IRS set the fee at full cost or obtain a waiver from OMB. IRM

) Anyone who prepares or substantially helps to prepare any federal tax or claim for refund of compensation must have a valid IRS PTIN, which renewed annually beginning in October for the next ﬁling season. (
) The PTIN applications and renewals are processed through a third-party tractor that also collects the IRS user fee and a separate contractor fee. (
) The contractor that processes the applications and renewals submits the user fees to the IRS through Pay.gov. Advanced Art (
) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for performing an advanced art valuation. IRM

) Taxpayers can request art valuations for income, estate or gift tax purposes. The Office of Art Appraisal Services under the chief, Appeals, reviews the market value claims on works of art and issues a Statement of Value. Taxpayers can rely on the Statement of Value for completing tax returns statements are based on facts. (

) A taxpayer seeking a Statement of Value: a. Submits a copy of a qualiﬁed appraisal of the art item(s) b. Pays the user fee c. Completes and submits an appraisal summary d. Identiﬁes the jurisdiction for examination of the taxpayer’s tax return (
) Advanced art valuation determination fees are collected through Pay.gov. Rulings (
) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for providing rulings and determination letters. IRM (
) Chief Counsel provides letter rulings, closing agreements and determination letters to taxpayers upon request. (
) Taxpayers pay the user fee on Pay.gov and submit a copy of the payment voucher with their requests for letter rulings or determinations.
The PTIN applications and renewals are processed through a third-party con- tractor that also collects the IRS user fee and a separate contractor fee.
The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for performing an advanced art valuation. IRM 1.35.19.4 (1)
The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for providing rulings and determination letters. IRM 1.35.19.4
Taxpayers pay the user fee on Pay.gov and submit a copy of the payment voucher with their requests for letter rulings or determinations.

) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for providing employee plans and exempt organizations with determinations letters, information letters and other guidance. IRM

) The TE/GE division provides letter rulings, determination letters, information letters and other guidance for employee plans and exempt organizations. The Cost Accounting and User Fees office maintains a list of the various fee cat- egories and rates. (
) The TE/GE division receives fees at the Cincinnati Submission Processing Center and through Pay.gov. (
) The Cincinnati Submission Processing Center deposits payments through the deposit function at the campus and records user fee deposits in RRACS. (

) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for providing a taxpayer with pre ﬁling agreements, federal excise tax exemptions, tax treaty limitation of beneﬁts interpretations and advanced pricing agreements. IRM

) Taxpayers serviced by LB&I can request a pre-ﬁling agreement, which is con- sideration of an issue before ﬁling a tax return. The LB&I division sends a fee invoice to the taxpayer if the request is accepted. The taxpayer submits payment for the user fee to Pay.gov or to the Government Payables and Funds Management office, which notiﬁes LB&I of receipt. (
) The LB&I division receives requests from taxpayers for federal excise tax ex- emptions and tax treaty limitation of beneﬁts interpretations through a PO Box or through Pay.gov. (

) Taxpayers may request an advanced pricing agreement to resolve actual or potential transfer pricing disputes as an alternative to the traditional examina- tion process. The LB&I division receives transfer pricing agreements requests and user fees through a PO Box or Pay.gov. (
) Payments received through a PO Box are mailed to Government Payables Funds Management for deposit. (
) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for providing taxpayers with a U.S. residency certiﬁcation.

) A U.S. residency certiﬁcation conﬁrms a person is a U.S. resident who ﬁles a U.S. tax return. Some income tax treaties between the U.S. and foreign countries can reduce withholding from certain types of income paid to U.S. residents. Treaty partners sometimes require the IRS to certify residency of individual claiming treaty beneﬁts. (
) To receive a letter of U.S. residency certiﬁcation, taxpayers ﬁle Form
, plication for United States Residency Certiﬁcation, and submit the appropriate user fee to the IRS. (
) The IRS receives U.S. residency certiﬁcation user fees through Pay.gov. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The IRS receives U.S. residency certiﬁcation user fees through Pay.gov.
Veriﬁcation Service (

) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for administering the Income Veriﬁcation Express Service (IVES) program for approved customers who have signed up for this service. IRM
) The IVES program provides taxpayer transcripts to customers within two business days. Users fax Form
-T, Request for Transcript of Tax Return, signed by the taxpayer, to the campuses that process the request through Transcript Delivery System. (

) The IRS records IVES user fees using the accrual basis of accounting. The Transcript Delivery System transmits the transcripts to customers during the month, interfacing with IFS at month-end to generate invoices based on the number of transcripts provided and to record revenue and receivables. (

) Approved customers pay electronically via debit or credit card through Pay.gov. The Financial Management Systems office pulls an IVES report from Pay.gov and uploads the report into IFS daily. This process records customer payments and reverses receivables. of and Business (
) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the cost for photocopying a taxpayer’s individual and/or business return. IRM
) Taxpayers can obtain copies of their tax returns and attachments for the current year and three prior years by submitting Form
, Request for of Tax Return. (
) The campuses receive payments for photocopy user fees and record the in RRACS as user fee revenue. of Organizations (
) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the costs for providing an electronic copy of an exempt organization tax return to a taxpayer. IRM
) The Ogden campus receives requests and payments for copies of exempt ganization tax returns. Studies (
) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the costs for creating and providing taxpayers with statistical studies requested by the public. IRM

) Taxpayers submit a written request to the director of Research, Applied Analytics, and Statistics. The Statistics of Income division estimates the cost providing the service and sends an invoice to the taxpayer or directs the taxpayer to the published prices on the current Statistics of Income Bulletin. (
) The Statistics of Income division receives payments through Pay.gov or a Box and sends any paper checks received to the Government Payables and Funds Management office for processing. Fees

) The IRS charges a fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the costs for providing a copy of a written determination to a taxpayer. IRM
) The IRS provides taxpayers with copies of written determination background ﬁle documents. (

) Taxpayers submit written requests to Chief Counsel, who estimates the cost providing the service and sends a payment agreement to the taxpayer. Chief Counsel processes the request after the payment has been received. (
) Chief Counsel receives payments through Pay.gov and matches payments the submitted applications.

) The IRS charges a fee set at $
by legislation for the historical conservation easement charitable deduction. IRM
) A taxpayer who claims the historical conservation easement charitable deduction on his or her tax return must pay a user fee and submit Form Noncash Charitable Contributions, along with the fee. (
) The IRS receives the user fee through the Government Payables and Funds Management office through Pay.gov. (
) The Government Payables and Funds Management office notiﬁes the Ogden Campus to record the transaction on the master ﬁle taxpayer’s record.
) Freedom of Information Requests (
) The IRS charges a reasonable fee, which may be less than full cost, to recover the costs for providing taxpayers with information that falls under Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). IRM

) The FOIA mandates public access to the records of federal agencies unless the information involved is protected from disclosure by one of FOIA’s nine emptions or three exclusions. The Office of Privacy, Governmental Liaison Disclosure administers the FOIA program. (
USC

, Public information, agency rules, opinions, orders, records, and proceedings, requires federal agencies to impose reasonable standard fees recover direct costs except when the information disclosed is in the public’s interest. Agencies are precluded by law from imposing fees if the cost of col- lection exceeds the amount collected. (
) The taxpayer agrees to pay in advance if the FOIA request is estimated to exceed $

) The Office of Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure receives FOIA user fees through a PO Box and forwards the payments to the Government Payables and Funds Management office via overnight mail. IRM
